Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US expresses a sense of entitlement to sit where it pleases - "waiting my turn" -, while the Dutch continue with their long-standing tradition of queueing (the 10-minute extended coffee breaks are just another reinforcement for queue-lines in anticipation). Which one is right? Which one is 'just common sense'?, or which

After watching this movie, I couldn't help but notice the parallels between it and another film called America 3000. Both were very bad mid 1980's scifi movies that feature a girl who fantasizes about robots (like Wall-e) making her life better. In both cases she risks everything to escape into a Utopia like one ruled by robots.
The only difference was that in America 3000, her boyfriend comes along as his role is diminished.

While credited as a Tom and Jerry cartoon, this is not the cat-and-mouse team but an earlier Mutt-and-Jeff rip-off featuring them going about to survive in today's turbulent economy. In the end, they channel their problems over into other people's families and homes during busy party moments. Their schemes can be quite devastating but meet with satisfaction from their recent unemployment status.
This short spoofs cut development films with a "Mickey Mouse" theme of unemployment woes

Snow White is in my opinion a bad movie on an artistic point of view. The plot is pretty much foreseeable, the characters are stereotypes, the editing too. But it’s got vibes that pulls you back again to watch it.
I was really happy to find this full length version of Snow White on YouTube and I adore Brother Bear’s new guitar tune “Yum Yum” as well as the reprise – found both at 2:11 and 3:10

What is left of Planet Earth is populated by a few poor and starving rag-tag survivors. They must eat bugs and insects, or whatever they can find. The wealthy fliers have long since left Planet Earth, for adventures in the countless empires that make up the Galaxy beyond. STOCKART: A dish to feed flies. Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is clearly an attempt to catch the wave of martial arts popularity ; It borrows many characteristics from other better Ninja and similar themed films such as Big trouble in Little China, Breakin', Revenge of The Ninja, Revenge of The Ninja 2 , American Samurai (Sword of Bushido
